item.title: PC candidate accused of threat against community member says allegation 'fabricated'
item.description: A PC candidate in Scarborough who is being investigated by Toronto police for allegedly making a written threat against a community member says the email containing the threat is fabricated.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Freeman
item.enclosure: Ontario PC leader Doug Ford shakes hands with candidate Roshan Nallaratnam (left) after making a campaign announcement in Toronto on Monday, June 4, 2018. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Frank Gunn

item.title: Coroner defends calling the death of Millard's father a suicide
item.description: The coroner who initially ruled an aviation executive's death a suicide told a murder trial Monday that he believed there was a "reasonable chance" Wayne Millard killed himself, but noted it was possible someone else pulled the trigger of the gun found beside the man.
item.dc:creator: Liam Casey
item.enclosure: Dellen Millard appears in court on May 31, 2018. (John Mantha)

item.title: ‘We are not apathetic’: 3.5 million voters in the Ontario election are under 25
item.description: According to the most recent census, there are over 3.5 million Ontario residents – and potential voters --between the ages of 18 and 25. This age group, once called apathetic, is now a driving force in politics.
item.dc:creator: Katherine DeClerq
item.enclosure: Ontario Liberal Party Leader Kathleen Wynne meets a young student before a roundtable discussion on education at the University of Waterloo during a campaign stop on Friday, June 1, 2018. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Andrew Ryan

item.title: Still no sign of man abducted in Rexdale after 'demands for money' met, police say
item.description: There is still no sign of a missing 26-year-old man who police say was abducted outside a Rexdale restaurant on Friday night.
item.dc:creator: Codi Wilson
item.enclosure: Jammar Allison appears in this undated photo provided by Toronto police.

item.title: Wynne makes last-ditch effort to warn voters of NDP, PC majorities
item.description: Ontario's Liberal premier is making last-ditch efforts to warn voters away from electing a majority NDP or Progressive Conservative government, after admitting over the weekend that her party can't win Thursday's election.
item.dc:creator: Paola Loriggio
item.enclosure: Ontario Liberal Party Leader Kathleen Wynne makes an announcement at the University of Waterloo during a campaign stop in Waterloo, Ont., on Friday, June 1, 2018. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Andrew Ryan

item.title: Suspect accused in murder of Toronto mother appears in court
item.description: The man accused of killing a mother of three inside her East York home last weekend appeared in court today.
item.dc:creator: Rachael D'Amore
item.enclosure: Yosin Murillo appears in court on a charge of first-degree murder on June 4, 2018. (Sketch by John Mantha)

item.title: Hamilton police arrest 3 more suspects in Locke Street vandalism
item.description: Police in Hamilton say they’re arrested three more suspects in connection with a vandalism spree that left businesses, homes and vehicles damaged back in March.
item.enclosure: Hamilton police have issued Canada-wide arrest warrants for Alexander Bach, 34, Matthew Lowell-Pelletier, 31, and David Prychitka, 34, in relation to the Locke Street vandalism spree. (Hamilton Police handout)

item.title: Burlington Street East in Hamilton tops CAA's list of worst roads in Ontario
item.description: The Canadian Automobile Association says Hamilton's Burlington Street East tops its survey of the worst roads in Ontario for the second consecutive year.
item.enclosure: The Canadian Automobile Association South Central Ontario launches its annual Worst Roads campaign on Tuesday, March 25, 2014.

item.title: GTA voters say they want land transfer tax gone as home sales dip
item.description: A majority of voters in the Greater Toronto Area say they want Ontario's next government to do away with the province's land transfer tax, according to a poll.
item.dc:creator: Tara Deschamps

item.title: Caesars Windsor workers ratify new contract, ending 60-day strike
item.description: Caesars Windsor says the casino resort will reopen on Thursday now that striking workers have agreed to a new contract.
item.enclosure: Caesars Windsor is shown in this file photo in Windsor, Ont., on Nov. 16, 2012. (Melanie Borrelli / CTV Windsor)
